awd_titl_txt: Center for Integrative Research in Computing and Learning Sciences (CIRCLS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Artificial intelligence and other emerging technologies are transforming learning across the lifespan within home, community, educational and workplace settings. Harnessing these advanced technologies to address nationally-important learning needs in STEM (and STEM-enabling areas) requires the integration of interdisciplinary research in the learning and computer sciences. The mission of the Center for Integrative Research in Computing and Learning Sciences (CIRCLS) is to: a) connect NSF-funded learning technology researchers and serve as a community-based hub across the interdisciplinary research community (to include learning sciences, computer sciences, social sciences, and engineering);  and, b) support the field by synthesizing emerging insights, findings and advances in ways that strengthen learning with emerging technology.  As a center, CIRCLS will bring investigators together to share expertise, coordinate efforts, and synthesize knowledge across projects. This includes a strong focus on broadening participation among graduate students, early career scholars, equity scholars, and practitioners - aiming to serve a field with over 1,000 active participants. In addition, CIRCLS will communicate widely to broader research and development audiences and policy makers regarding research advances through its newsletter, website, reports and events. 

Specifically, CIRCLS will lead six activities that go beyond the reach of existing conferences, societies and journals to foster synergies among computer scientists, learning scientists and relevant disciplines. The interrelated activities include the following: (1) Hosting bi-annual multi-disciplinary research convenings in a highly interactive format that builds relationships, identifies priority issues for emerging learning technologies, and focuses on collectively advancing research to address tensions and challenges; (2) Building capacity around artificial intelligence synergies within education via working groups for graduate students and early career scientists across locations to tackle tough problems that transcend any individual project; (3) Organizing field-driven research syntheses, to generate concise, compelling summaries across projects on topics that are foundational to the work or reflect emerging designs and insights; (4) Expanding reach, engagement and dissemination of the field’s research, focused on broader audiences to include researchers, policy makers, educational practitioners, and other interest groups, through a mix of social media, newsletters and other effective formats; (5) Curating the portfolio of awards to collect and report detailed, consistent information about funded research, which will help the field to understand the state of the art, to analyze of advances and gaps, and to plan the future; and (6) Gathering community feedback and engaging an advisory group composed of leaders from multiple disciplinary perspectives to guide continuous improvement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Integrative Research in Computing and Learning Sciences (CIRCLS) has been a community-based hub for researchers who explore and investigate emerging technologies for teaching and learning. The community consists of awardees in the Research in Emerging Technologies for Teaching and Learning (RETTL), Research on Innovative Technologies for Enhanced Learning (RITEL) program, and other thematically-related awards throughout NSF. Specific investigators in the community tackle the future of learning in subjects that have national importance, including STEM learning and future-oriented workforce learning. The Center brought investigators together with three major goals: (1) to share expertise, (2) to collaborate across disciplines on challenging issues, and (3) to synthesize knowledge and insights across projects. Two cross-cutting themes were prominent: (1) addressing ethics and equity and (2) integrating computer and learning sciences perspectives. Although the focus initially was on the future, as Generative AI rose in importance in society, the work of the CIRCLS community became immediately relevant. For example, with regard to generative AI, CIRCLS has actively informed and supported not only researchers but also educators, policymakers, and emerging scholars. 

The most notable broader impact was this community's role in bridging from research to policy through workshops and contributions to a federal policy report entitled, "AI and the Future of Learning and Teaching: Insights and Recommendations" (Department of Education, 2022). Many NSF-funded researchers in our community shared insights and recommendations that appear in this landmark report.

Yet the most enduring impact likely arose through CIRCL's highly interactive activities, which enabled researchers to connect with each other and formulate new research questions and project ideas, brought emerging scholars and educators into greater participation in the research process, and enabled all to work as a community to envision what research would be most important in the coming years.

Additional highlights include the following:

CIRCLS hosted two highly interactive convenings with over 500 participants in total,  CIRCLS'21: Remaking Broadening and CIRCLS'23: Shaping AI and Emerging Technologies to Empower Learning Communities. Each brought attendees together to engage in thought-provoking discussions about how the field can leverage emerging technologies for teaching and learning. Honorariums were provided for over 30 educators, emerging scholars, youth, and researchers who had not yet been funded. CIRCLS cultivated a diverse community. Each convening included a "town hall" which generated recommendations for the field going forward.

CIRCLS facilitated collaborative working groups: AI CIRCLS, Educator CIRCLS, and Emerging Scholar CIRCLS for "Expertise Exchanges" within the community. These exchanges built capacity and promoted interdisciplinary partnerships via activities such as webinars, mentoring series, research interest affinity groups, policy discussions, project incubators, mock review panels, and more. For example, Educator CIRCLS produced 50 blog posts featuring educators' perspectives on emerging technologies.

In collaboration with the International Society of the Learning Sciences, CIRCLS also produced Rapid Community Reports (RCRs) to share insights from exploratory research. These 17 publications filled the gaps in knowledge dissemination based on either conferences and traditional publications.  Similarly, CIRCLS collaborated with the Journal of Computing in Higher Education (JCHE) on a special issue on AI and education equity in higher education.

Additionally, we developed a 144 page website (circls.org) and maintained a strong social media presence to share publications, solicitations, and resources (e.g., open access external primers and reading lists) for our community along with distributing CIRCLS newsletters to over 5,400 subscribers. Our website also featured spotlighted projects, a project tag map, and a brokering tool to find projects of interest, seek out additional expertise in an area, or identify potential collaborators. To further amplify the work of the portfolio, we facilitated the production of 51 project information pages.

CIRCLS supported three postdocs, all who subsequently accepted learning sciences positions at prominent research institutions. Additionally, we supported 165 emerging scholars, engaged 150 educators, and hosted AI working groups for 150 participants from a variety of disciplines spanning academia, industry, non-profits, and practitioners.

Lastly, CIRCLS worked with members of the community to produce two featured reports. Our 2023 report entitled, "Partnerships for Change: Transforming Research on Emergent Learning Technologies" provides deep insights into how multidisciplinary research partnerships in our research topic area (emerging technologies for teaching and learning) are formed; what kinds of research challenges they are able to tackle together; and how the research tangible changes for the better when partnerships succeed.  Our 2024 report entitled, "Unveiling the Value of Exploration: Insights from NSF-Funded Research on Emerging Technologies for Teaching and Learning" discusses the value of exploratory research with insights and findings from our community. By better understanding the character of this work, both NSF and the field can optimize their proposals and projects to realize the opportunity of exploratory research for technological areas that are rapidly evolving and for applications (like education) that require uncovering and responding to complex human patterns of interaction.

These and other CIRCLS outputs are available at https://circls.org
